text: as the Sun sets across rural Africa
children rush to finish their tasks and
school work before darkness descends
when there was no kerosene we could not
even study now it's very easy because we
just turn on the lights and start
studying this is Elizabeth Rosenthal
reporting from Kipp to Surrey Kenya
light and the opportunity it brings are
new to many of these villages these LED
lamps run off batteries charged by new
solar panels long stuck in energy
poverty rural Africa is getting its
first drops of electricity my child who
was 20th in his class has risen to fit
because he has a chance to study longer
at night the moment the Sun hits the
panel's at 6:30 in the morning
everything starts charging even on a
cloudy day when there is no Sun the
solar panels keep charging for Sarah in
addition to providing power for lights
it charges her mobile phone
Skoda a nonprofit has been searching for
ways to power rural areas it seized
renewables as a long-awaited answer so
the energy was dedicated adventure
small-scale sustainable energy projects
are popping up all over Africa from
solar crop dryers to energy efficient
cookstoves to backyard systems that
convert cow manure into cooking fuel
power and light have also allowed
businesses to prosper into the night but
it may be the families that benefit most
with power providing freedom from the
idle darkness of night if you turn the
lights on now people from all around
town will see the lights of our home
from far away it is very bright people
are very surprised to see the light in
our village for the first time they were
very curious and would always ask about
it also my children were so excited they
wanted me to sell my chickens to buy
more lights for MS ruto and others these
lights provide a little bit of
illumination for her to find her way
home
